Thousands of splendid edifices will display their archilcc-J
tural proportions, for miles up and down yonder magnificent j
river. Long lines of floating palaces, will attest the general!
prosperity; and the dense forests of masts, stretching in]
length, with the increase of population, will characterize I
New Orleans as one of the proudest commercial cities in
the world.
But, Mr. President and gentlemen, in pursuing this vision
of-the future glory of the capital of my native slate, I find
that I have consumed more of your time than I had intended. Let Rie conclude by saying that we have been too long!
indifferent to the improvement of our country, and the dcvc-i
lopmcnt of its vast resources. Let us participate less in]
sectional and political agitations, and embark energetically
in those public improvements, without which we can never]
become a great and prosperous state. The fame which,
great leaders and statesmen have left behind them, has been!
measured, not so much by the mere triumphs of intellect, or]
splendid achievements on the field of battle, as by the benc-j
fitfthey have conferred on society, in promoting works of'
greilt practical utility. When the glories of Austerlitz and!
Marengo shall have been forgotten, the name of Napoleon!
will be associated in undying lustre, with the great public!
works which his genius and his energy promotcel in France. I
And if Americans can ever forget to associate the name of]
Washington with the battle-fields of the revolution; bisl
chief glory vvill be derived from his ardor, in promoting the 1
peaceful development of the country, whose freedom bad
been purchased by his sword. Let us, also, by our united I
exertions, command the homage of those that are to follow j
us, by constructing a work of great public utility, which will j
be our proudest monument hereafter.
On motion of E. H. Martin, the Convention tlicnl
adjourned to meet to-morrow evening at half past 0
